I have one wish, and one wish only (which I‚Äôve had the previous two years)‚Ä¶.system wide dark mode. Don‚Äôt let me down Apple. üôè

Tony 10

May 17, 2018

I recently watched ‚ÄúAll Bets Are Off‚Äù 1, a documentary hosted by Baz Ashmawy about gambling addiction in Ireland. One of the people featured on the documentary was Tony O‚Äô Reilly, a former branch manager at An Post who stole a mind boggling ¬Ä‚Ç¨1.7 million from his employers and managed to win an even more mind boggling ¬Ä‚Ç¨10 million, only to lose it all. ‚ÄòTony 10‚Äô was the username of his online betting account.

Tony, along with author Declan Lynch, recently released a book, ‚ÄúTony 10: The astonishing story of the postman who gambled ¬Ä‚Ç¨10,000,000‚Ä¶ and lost it all‚Äù, documenting his story from falling into gambling addiction to eventually overcoming it and becoming an addiction counsellor himself - not before spending time in jail and losing just about everything in between.

The book opens by painting a picture of an ordinary man in an ordinary town. What begins with a ¬Ä‚Ç¨1 bet ‚Äúto have an interest‚Äù in some of the 1998 World Cup matches escalates into a world where numbers have no meaning. ¬Ä‚Ç¨10000 on a tennis match, ¬Ä‚Ç¨20000 on a horse may as well be ‚Ç¨¬Ä1 or ‚Ç¨¬Ä2 bets.

The big take away from reading the book is that it is extremely easy to get sucked into gambling addiction. Betting shops are in every town in Ireland and online betting is available to anybody at any place and time.

The fact that Tony O‚ÄôReilly was able to walk into betting offices with enormous amounts of money in cash and could bet that money away day after day without any questions being asked makes you wonder how often this type of thing happens, and how betting organizations are getting away with it.

Tony 10 is an interesting read, and one which gives a great insight into the power of addiction and how easy it is to lose the run of yourself.

  1. Highly recommended by the way. At the time of writing this, it can still be watched on the RTE Player. ↩

May 2, 2018

Developer Steve Troughton Smith today tweeted photos of macOS 10.14 with some very juicy details about Apple‚Äôs upcoming operating system. The OS is very clearly sporting a fresh new dark theme, presumably a toggle-able setting, with the dark UI affecting all application chrome. You can also see an icon for a Mac News app in the Dock, as well as a first look at Xcode 10.

Why I love link blogging‚Üí

April 20, 2018

Matt Birchler, on why he loves writing linked posts on his site:

More often than not, I write articles for this site after reading something someone else wrote. I browse the web for articles and tweets that I find interesting, and the ones that make me think are very often the ones that inspire me to write something myself.

This leads to a funny situation as a writer though: do I write my article as a brand new post that gives the impression I thought of something in a vacuum? Do I write a normal post and link to the article/tweet that inspired me inline? Do I do a full block quote that shows off what idea got me going and write from there?

I personally love the third option. Link to someone else, provide a relatively short block quote of what idea set me off, and then take on the topic from there.

The web allows us to create content that is connected with the rest of the web. Everything we do, especially us writers, is kicked off by something someone else said, and we should embrace that. Make your blog a part of a conversation, not an island that feels like you‚Äôre just doing this all on your own. None of us are, and we should be proud of that.

Besides, if someone reads my site and I link somewhere else, hopefully that will make people click that link and some of them will discover a new writer they had never heard of. If that linked article also links somewhere else, then the rabbit hole can get very deep, but that‚Äôs just more chances to find some gems out there.

Couldn‚Äôt agree more.

Blogging System Rewrite‚Üí

April 15, 2018

Brent Simmons, describing the recent changes he has made to his blog:

I realized that I want my blog to be me on the web. This used to be true, but then along came Twitter, and then my presence got split up between two places.

To make this work, I needed two things that my old system from 2009 didn‚Äôt provide:

  1. Title-less posts, and
  2. The ability to run the site generator on my server, not just on my Mac.

In other words, I needed to be able to write tweet-like posts with no title ‚Äî while on the go, on my iPhone or iPad.

It‚Äôs interesting to see the influence that Micro.blog has had on the blogging community. I‚Äôm seeing more and more of this style of posting.

Blogs set up with microblogging are interesting to read. It‚Äôs like having a Twitter feed with occasional long form blog posts sandwiched in-between.

The ability to cross post to social media ensures that you can keep your output under your control, as it always lives on your own site.

This is not something I see myself setting up as I don‚Äôt really post enough on social media to justify it, but it‚Äôs a smart move for anyone concerned with owning their own identify.

How the new 9.7-inch iPad stacks up against the iPad Pro‚Üí

April 6, 2018

Nice comparison on 9to5mac between the new 9.7-inch iPad and the iPad Pro line. That new iPad at ‚Ç¨369.99 is a great buy. The only real downside between it an the Pro line is the screen, which lacks ProMotion and True Tone. Neither of those technologies are complete deal breakers, but the gap in display quality would definitely be noticable in a side by side comparison.

The Pro line of iPads are great, but at an entry level price of ‚Ç¨749.99 for the 10.5-inch model, I just struggle to see what that extra ‚Ç¨380 really gets you. The Pro line will likely see an update this summer so I would expect some new features that should blow the 9.7-inch iPad out of the water, but for sure it‚Äôs still a great tablet for the price.

Loving Diamonds Are Forever‚Üí

March 25, 2018

On the surface, Diamonds Are Forever is a terrible film. It marked Connery‚Äôs comeback, after a four year absence, and unfortunately he no longer seemed to fit the role. By then, he was a little pudgier, less dynamic, and he often looked bored on screen. Perhaps Connery was attempting to play off the film‚Äôs overall tone. Diamonds was the first Bond film to delve into camp and comedy. The results would appear mixed, at best. Though the film has received its share of positive reviews over the years, it is mostly ranked in the ‚Äúbottom tier‚Äù on critics‚Äô and fans‚Äô Bond lists.

Some Bond films are so different that is hard to believe they are part of the same franchise at all. If you were to compare Diamonds Are Forever to On Her Majesty‚Äôs Secret Service (which came out just two years beforehand) you would be hard pushed to find any similarities at all.

As much as I enjoy Daniel Craig‚Äôs more gritty and realistic portrayal of the character, I always find myself leaning towards Roger Moore‚Äôs Bonds when I just want to sit down and be entertained. The same goes for Diamonds Are Forever as outlined in the linked article.

It shouldn‚Äôt work, and to the majority of people it doesn‚Äôt work, but I really enjoy Bond movies that don‚Äôt take themselves too seriously. What Bond films have I seen most? Probably Moonraker and The Man With The Golden Gun - both of which are consistently ranked at or near the bottom of the Bond films.

That‚Äôs what‚Äôs great about the Bonds. Some people can‚Äôt stand Roger Moore. Some people think Timothy Dalton is the unsung hero. Others think anything before Daniel Craig‚Äôs films can be disregarded. There‚Äôs something for everyone.

My blogging workflow‚Üí

March 2, 2018

An interesting post by David Sparks over on MacSparky about the general workflow he uses for publishing on his blog. He treats long form posts as projects which require mind maps, an editor and a most importantly, time.

Most of what I write on this site are small, linked posts, but for longer posts there are some great pieces of information that I can take from David‚Äôs workflow.

Tools for the job are another story that mostly comes down to personal preference. I use a combination of text editors to write my posts, most of which depend on the device I‚Äôm using. I would love for a built-in Markdown editor to be added to the GitHub file editor, but for now I will continue to use what I always do.

For reference, I use:

  • Sublime Text
  • 1Writer
  • Dillinger

Why Micro.blog is not another App.net‚Üí

February 10, 2018

Brent Simmons on Micro.blog:

Your posts are just a normal, everyday part of the open web. At this writing, mine appear on micro.inessential.com ‚Äî but it‚Äôs on my to-do list to have those appear on my main blog (this blog) instead. (Probably won‚Äôt happen until after I ship the app I‚Äôm currently working on.)

And this is how it used to be, and how it never should have stopped being: my blog is me on the web. I own my blog: I own me.

And so everyone who follows me on Micro.blog sees my blog posts, and I see theirs. Simple.

And anyone who wants to could just read my blog in an RSS reader instead. All good, all open.
